articles.headline: Bernanke Talks Tough on Inflation
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke avoided repeating an earlier suggestion of a pause in the Fed's two-year program of interest-rate increases.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke avoided repeating an earlier suggestion of a pause in the Fed's two-year program of interest-rate increases.

articles.headline: M.S. Drug Can Return, With Limits
articles.snippet: Regulators agreed to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease.
articles.abstract: Regulators agreed to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators agreed yesterday to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease, under a program intended to closely monitor doctors who prescribe it and patients who use it.

articles.headline: Biotech Food Tears Rifts in Europe
articles.snippet: Though the E.U. said biotech food must be allowed in, five countries have imposed bans, and others use Europe's Council of Ministers to block the crops from entering.
articles.abstract: Though the E.U. said biotech food must be allowed in, five countries have imposed bans, and others use Europe's Council of Ministers to block the crops from entering.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In this famously fractious country, there is one thing on which almost all Greeks agree: They do not want genetically modified crops grown, sold or eaten here.

articles.headline: Somali Islamists Declare Victory; Warlords on Run
articles.snippet: The end of fighting raises new questions about whether an Islamic regime will steer Somalia down an extremist path.
articles.abstract: The end of fighting raises new questions about whether an Islamic regime will steer Somalia down an extremist path.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 5 — After months of fierce fighting, Islamic militias declared Monday that they had taken control of Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, defeating the warlords widely believed to be backed by the United States and raising questions about whether the country would head down an extremist path.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Offering Deals on Trade to Entice Iran
articles.snippet: The incentives include a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet by purchasing parts from Boeing.
articles.abstract: The incentives include a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet by purchasing parts from Boeing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5 — The European Union's foreign policy director, Javier Solana, arrived in Tehran on Monday night with incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, including a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet through the purchase of aircraft parts from an American company, Boeing.

articles.headline: New Frontiers in Takeout
articles.snippet: Family-style restaurants now offer curbside dining, where customers have meals brought to their cars as they sit idling outside.
articles.abstract: Family-style restaurants now offer curbside dining, where customers have meals brought to their cars as they sit idling outside.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, harried Americans have flocked to fast-food drive-through windows, looking to save a few precious minutes in their busy days.

articles.headline: For Law Firm, Serial Plaintiff Had Golden Touch
articles.snippet: A long-running arrangement allegedly helped one law firm reap hundreds of millions of dollars in legal fees on securities lawsuits.
articles.abstract: A long-running arrangement allegedly helped one law firm reap hundreds of millions of dollars in legal fees on securities lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it came to investing, Howard J. Vogel seemed to possess a perverse kind of Midas touch.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Bernanke Talks Tough on Inflation
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned Monday that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he was far less worried about signs of weaker economic growth than about the danger of higher prices.    ...
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned Monday that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he was far less worried about signs of weaker economic growth than about the danger of higher prices.      In his toughest comments yet about the risks of inflation, Mr. Bernanke said consumer prices were rising faster than he would like. He gave short shrift to evidence of a slowdown in hiring, and he conspicuously avoided repeating his earlier suggestion that the Fed might consider a ''pause'' in its two-year program of steady interest rate increases.

articles.headline: Biotech Food Tears Rifts in Europe
articles.snippet: In this famously fractious country, there is one thing on which almost all Greeks agree: They do not want genetically modified crops grown, sold or eaten here.     ''All political parties are opposed,'' said Theodore Koliopanos, a legislator and f...
articles.abstract: In this famously fractious country, there is one thing on which almost all Greeks agree: They do not want genetically modified crops grown, sold or eaten here.     ''All political parties are opposed,'' said Theodore Koliopanos, a legislator and former deputy environment minister, ''which is odd because we disagree on everything else.''
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS - In this famously fractious country, there is one thing on which almost all Greeks agree: They do not want genetically modified crops grown, sold or eaten here.

articles.headline: House at Stake, Midterm Election Gets Early Start
articles.snippet: Congressional campaigns have begun early and with unusual intensity this year in many districts across the country, reflecting a consensus in both parties that Republicans could lose control of the House and perhaps the Senate.     A special elect...
articles.abstract: Congressional campaigns have begun early and with unusual intensity this year in many districts across the country, reflecting a consensus in both parties that Republicans could lose control of the House and perhaps the Senate.     A special election in a bedrock Republican Congressional district in San Diego on Tuesday -- for the seat left vacant when Representative Randy Cunningham resigned after pleading guilty to corruption charges -- has sharpened the early intensity and could provide the clearest evidence so far about whether Democrats can capitalize on the unsettled political climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5 - Congressional campaigns have begun early and with unusual intensity this year in many districts across the country, reflecting a consensus in both parties that Republicans could lose control of the House and perhaps the Senate.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Offering Deals on Trade to Entice Iran
articles.snippet: The European Union's foreign policy director, Javier Solana, arrived in Tehran on Monday night with incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, including a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet through the...
articles.abstract: The European Union's foreign policy director, Javier Solana, arrived in Tehran on Monday night with incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, including a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet through the purchase of aircraft parts from an American company, Boeing.      The package, to be presented Tuesday to Foreign Minister Manouchehr Mottaki and to Iran's chief nuclear negotiator, Ali Larijani, is to include waiving trade sanctions against Iran to allow the purchase of American agricultural technology, said European diplomats and a senior Bush administration official.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5 - The European Union's foreign policy director, Javier Solana, arrived in Tehran on Monday night with incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, including a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet through the purchase of aircraft parts from an American company, Boeing.

articles.headline: For Law Firm, Serial Plaintiff Had Golden Touch
articles.snippet: When it came to investing, Howard J. Vogel seemed to possess a perverse kind of Midas touch.      In early October 1997, he bought 50 shares of Oxford Health Plans. Three weeks later, the stock nose-dived, and Mr. Vogel lost about $3,000 of his in...
articles.abstract: When it came to investing, Howard J. Vogel seemed to possess a perverse kind of Midas touch.      In early October 1997, he bought 50 shares of Oxford Health Plans. Three weeks later, the stock nose-dived, and Mr. Vogel lost about $3,000 of his investment. Still, Mr. Vogel reaped $1.1 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it came to investing, Howard J. Vogel seemed to possess a perverse kind of Midas touch.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Somali Islamists Declare Victory; Warlords on Run
articles.snippet: After months of fierce fighting, Islamic militias declared Monday that they had taken control of Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, defeating the warlords widely believed to be backed by the United States and raising questions about whether the country...
articles.abstract: After months of fierce fighting, Islamic militias declared Monday that they had taken control of Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, defeating the warlords widely believed to be backed by the United States and raising questions about whether the country would head down an extremist path.     The battle for Mogadishu has been a proxy war, of sorts, in the Bush administration's campaign against terrorism, with the warlords echoing Washington's goal of rooting out radical Islam and the presence of Al Qaeda in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 5 - After months of fierce fighting, Islamic militias declared Monday that they had taken control of Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, defeating the warlords widely believed to be backed by the United States and raising questions about whether the country would head down an extremist path.

articles.headline: Google Takes Aim at Excel
articles.snippet: Stepping up its attack on Microsoft's core business, Google plans to make available on Tuesday a test version of a Web-based spreadsheet program that is intended to make it simple to edit and share lists and data online.     The company said that ...
articles.abstract: Stepping up its attack on Microsoft's core business, Google plans to make available on Tuesday a test version of a Web-based spreadsheet program that is intended to make it simple to edit and share lists and data online.     The company said that the free program, called Google Spreadsheets, would be able to read and create files in the format used by Excel, the Microsoft spreadsheet software that is installed on millions of personal computers.

articles.headline: M.S. Drug Can Return, With Limits
articles.snippet: Federal regulators agreed yesterday to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease, under a program intended to closely monitor doctors who prescribe it and patients who use it.  ...
articles.abstract: Federal regulators agreed yesterday to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease, under a program intended to closely monitor doctors who prescribe it and patients who use it.      The drug was withdrawn early last year after only three months on the market, after its risks became evident, but a federal advisory panel recommended this past March that Tysabri be returned to the market. At that meeting, in sometimes tearful testimony, about two dozen people with multiple sclerosis told the committee they were willing to accept the risks of the drug because they viewed Tysabri as the best hope for slowing the progression of their debilitating disease. Tysabri's makers estimate that there may be as many as 150,000 multiple sclerosis patients in this country for whom other drugs are not effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators agreed yesterday to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease, under a program intended to closely monitor doctors who prescribe it and patients who use it.

articles.headline: Court to Weigh Race as Factor in School Rolls
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to rule on what measures, if any, public school systems may use to maintain racial balance in individual schools.      The eventual decision on whether they can take race into account could affect hundreds of sch...
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to rule on what measures, if any, public school systems may use to maintain racial balance in individual schools.      The eventual decision on whether they can take race into account could affect hundreds of school systems in all areas of the country. The court accepted challenges to plans in Louisville, Ky., where the schools were once racially segregated by law, and in Seattle, where segregation was never official but was widespread because of residential patterns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5 - The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to rule on what measures, if any, public school systems may use to maintain racial balance in individual schools.

articles.headline: New Frontiers in Takeout
articles.snippet: For years, harried Americans have flocked to fast-food drive-through windows, looking to save a few precious minutes in their busy days.     Now they're branching out. Family-style restaurants -- like Applebee's and Outback Steakhouse -- have been...
articles.abstract: For years, harried Americans have flocked to fast-food drive-through windows, looking to save a few precious minutes in their busy days.     Now they're branching out. Family-style restaurants -- like Applebee's and Outback Steakhouse -- have been offering curbside dining, where customers can have meals delivered to their cars as they sit idling outside the restaurant -- and the new offering is a hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, harried Americans have flocked to fast-food drive-through windows, looking to save a few precious minutes in their busy days.
